Serhiy Sydorenko: Our NATO membership is no longer a distant prospect.
Nine years ago, Ukrainian sociology showed that 67% of Ukrainians were against joining NATO, and only 18% of respondents were in favor.

After the Revolution of Dignity, Viktor Yanukovych's flight, the annexation of Crimea, and the start of the war in Donbas, the number of NATO opponents began to decline, while supporters, conversely, grew.
After the start of the full-scale war with Russia, Ukrainian sociologists recorded a record level of support for Ukraine's accession to NATO among Ukrainian citizens‚Äîover 75%.

Despite supporting Ukraine's NATO accession and the aid NATO provides during the war, there is now widespread criticism of the Alliance and its member countries‚Äîfor delayed weapons deliveries, refusing to close the skies, and reluctance to "provoke" Russia.

In addition, there is a significant risk that Ukraine will be forced to abandon its pursuit of Alliance membership due to Russia's stance, if this could stop the war and Ukraine receives reliable security guarantees, including military ones.

In the new episode of the podcast "Damn Questions," we talk with the editor of "European Truth" about how the Alliance has supported Ukraine since the Russian invasion, what NATO should be criticized for and where criticism is unwarranted, why our NATO membership prospects are closer than ever in history, and why the security guarantees discussed in negotiations with Russia could become a second Budapest Memorandum.

Last week, the Verkhovna Rada adopted draft law 7176, titled "On Monitoring Potential Threats to Ukraine's National Security in the Economic Sphere.

It is strange that the only potential threat to Ukraine‚Äôs national economic security turned out to be‚Ä¶ the seating arrangement for members of state-owned companies‚Äô and state banks‚Äô supervisory boards.
The initiators of the bill believe that decisions made by the supervisory board of the state-owned company in a hypothetical Kyiv could somehow address Ukraine's national security issues.
We are aware of numerous new threats to state-owned companies, but so far no company has been reported to require physically holding a supervisory board meeting at its registered address.

The potential threat of such a law is clear‚Äîit provides a perfect basis to dismantle all achievements in the difficult state enterprise reform after the Revolution of Dignity, including independent supervisory boards, and then establish manual control.
The same as it was before 2015.
Why do state-owned companies need supervisory boards and who should be on them?

Moreover, if one harmful bill is passed under patriotic slogans, others could follow tomorrow‚Äîfor example, dismantling the ProZorro public procurement system or undermining the independence of the National Bank of Ukraine.
Much can be blamed on the war.
By the way, this initiative emerged even before the start of the war and draft law 7176.
On February 22, this provision was also included in the comparative table of draft law 5397.
And overall, the desire to disband supervisory boards in one way or another has been circulating among some elected officials for a long time.
Not for the sake of criticism itself, but to demonstrate the potential consequences of the bill, let us examine the arguments that justified the need for its adoption.
And then we will present our proposals on how to address the issue of managing state-owned enterprises during the war.

The First Deputy Minister of Economy, Denys Kudin, explained the need for such an innovation by the risks of losing internet and other means of communication, which would make remote work of supervisory boards impossible.
In other words, the risk is that the supervisory board will be unable to make necessary decisions, which could paralyze the company's operations.
We agree that such a risk exists, but would relocating the supervisory board members to Ukraine prevent it?

Imagine a rather cynical situation where independent members of supervisory boards (who make up the majority of the entire board) prioritize their personal safety over the company's interests and refuse to come to Ukraine.
In this case, according to the bill, they can be dismissed.
And eventually, this will most likely lead to the loss of the quorum required by the supervisory board to make any decisions.
Instead, it will not be possible to quickly appoint new independent members to the supervisory board, as the law requires a competitive selection process that typically takes 3-4 months.
Therefore, the solution proposed by Draft Law 7176 is unlikely to prevent the supervisory board from losing its decision-making authority and will most likely lead to exactly that outcome!
People's Deputy and bill author Dmytro Natalukha provides other arguments in its support.

In particular, he notes: "many enterprises, especially those in the defense-industrial complex (DIC), now require relocation" and therefore "it is hard to imagine that a person could, for example, discuss addresses and other sensitive information via Zoom from Vienna.
To begin with, Ukraine has almost no state-owned defense enterprises with supervisory boards.
The supervisory board exists only in "Ukroboronprom," which essentially manages almost all state-owned enterprises in the defense industry.
But even in "Ukroboronprom," according to the law, the supervisory board has rather limited powers, and all its members perform their duties on a non-gratuitous basis.
All executive power in "Ukroboronprom" belongs to the general director, who will also make decisions regarding the necessity of relocating any defense industry enterprise within the concern.
Moreover, such an argument does not hold up to criticism because draft law 7176 does not introduce any changes to the legislation regulating the activities of state-owned defense enterprises.
Mr. Dmytro also presents arguments on his Facebook page that can be categorized as "emotional.

Such arguments typically have nothing to do with improving the efficiency of state-owned companies and state banks, but let‚Äôs try to examine some of them: "respected foreign experts, at the mere mention of 'war,' left Ukraine as early as 2021, yet remain members of supervisory boards at Ukrainian state enterprises with full salaries of several hundred thousand hryvnias, while Ukraine itself is actually suffering from the war.
First of all, it's manipulation‚Äîmost of these supervisory board members never lived in Ukraine and only visited here occasionally.
Therefore, saying that they are "leaving Ukraine" is, to put it mildly, unfair.
Secondly, due to the coronavirus pandemic, both foreign and Ukrainian members of supervisory boards have long resorted to the practice of holding online meetings.
This tool has long been widely used in global practice across completely different fields: business, education, medicine, and more.
It is also important to remember that membership on the supervisory board is not a full-time job.
As a rule, such people have other occupations as well, and electronic means of communication help them with this.
Thirdly, all these statements read as claims directed exclusively at foreigners.
Interestingly, why doesn‚Äôt Mr. Dmytro voice identical complaints against the members of the supervisory boards who are Ukrainians?
After all, they are also not at the location of their companies.
To be clear, this is far from the first populist attempt by MPs to remove foreigners from supervisory boards, and the war is merely a new convenient opportunity.

The US bans investments in Russia and imposes sanctions on Putin's daughters.

The United States, together with the G7 and the EU, is imposing new sanctions against the daughters of Russian President Putin, Russia's largest banks Alfa Bank and Sberbank, and banning all new investments in Russia.
This is mentioned in a statement on the White House website.
Sberbank is the largest financial institution in Russia, owned by the government, while Alfa-Bank is the largest private bank.
The sanctions will freeze any of their assets related to the U.S. financial system and prohibit U.S. citizens from doing business with them.
In addition, the United States will impose a complete ban on new investments in Russia.
With this goal in mind, U.S. President Joe Biden will sign a new executive order that includes a ban on new investments in Russia by U.S. citizens regardless of their location.
This step is based on the decision made by over 600 transnational companies to exit Russia.
The private sector includes manufacturers, energy companies, major retailers, financial institutions, and other service providers such as legal and consulting firms," the White House statement said.
The third step of the new U.S. sanctions involved restrictions against major Russian state-owned enterprises in critical sectors.
This will prohibit U.S. citizens from conducting transactions with these organizations and freeze any of their assets under U.S. jurisdiction.
The Ministry of Finance will publish the detailed list the following day, on Thursday.

The final part of the package is the complete freezing of assets of Putin's adult children, the wife and daughter of Foreign Minister Lavrov, as well as members of Russia's Security Council, including former president and prime minister Dmitry Medvedev and Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin.
The sanctions cut them off from the U.S. financial system and freeze all assets they hold in the United States.
